revised_title: Adaptive Sex Ratio Manipulation in Seychelles Warblers
tldr: Seychelles warblers adjust their offspring sex ratios based on territory quality. They produce more male offspring in low-quality territories and more female offspring in high-quality territories. This strategy helps parents gain or maintain helpers in high-quality territories, improving their reproductive success. The study provides evidence that this facultative sex ratio bias is caused by skewed offspring production rather than mortality differences.
scientific_discipline: Biology and Life Sciences > Ecology and Evolution
